sections.title: Introduction (Wide Shot)
sections.content: Welcome back! I’m Jihad Al Sayed, and in this lesson, we’re diving into the backbone of Linear Algebra — vector spaces and subspaces. Understanding these is key to grasping all the cool applications later like machine learning, graphics, and systems theory.

sections.title: What is a Vector Space?
sections.content: A vector space is a set of vectors that’s closed under addition and scalar multiplication. That means if you add two vectors or multiply one by a scalar, you're still inside the space.

sections.title: Common Examples
sections.content: ℝⁿ is a vector space. So is the set of all polynomials of degree ≤ n. Even function spaces can be vector spaces. If they follow the 10 vector space rules — they count.

sections.title: What is a Subspace?
sections.content: A subspace is just a smaller vector space sitting inside a larger one. For example, the set of all vectors lying on a plane through the origin is a subspace of ℝ³.

sections.title: Three Rules for Subspaces
sections.math:
1. Zero vector is in the set
2. Closed under addition
3. Closed under scalar multiplication

sections.title: Examples of Subspaces
sections.content: Null space, column space, and row space are all subspaces. You’ll see these come up constantly when solving Ax = b.

sections.title: Recap
sections.content: We now understand what vector spaces and subspaces are, what rules they follow, and how they show up in real problems. Mastering this makes everything else in linear algebra easier.
